profile: Bed Bug Removal And Pest Control Heat Treatment One Day Treatment: Bed Bugs Eradication within One Day. Bed Bugs Heat Treatment is the best safest technology to eliminate bed bugs quickly and permanently We kill bed bugs permanently *FREE QUOTE *100% Pesticide FREE - No Chemicals Required *No Additional Treatments Required *On call 24/7 - Same Day Service Available *All Other Insects, Pathogens & Allergens Dead *Serving Toronto and all of Ontario Our Products & Services Include *ThermaPureHeat a superior solution to red of bed bug infestations *Pesticide Treatment *Cockroach Removal and Prevention *NightWatch a revolutionary bio sensor bed bug detection system *PackTite heat chamber allows you to kill bed bugs on any item in your home or office at any time For helpful tips and information see our blog Why is Bed Bugs Heat Treatment Better than Using Chemicals? Historically, bed bug treatments have primarily used chemicals to reduce and control the pest. Recently, pesticides have shown to be ineffective in managing infestations with single bed bug treatments. An informal survey of pest control operators conducted by an entomologist at the University of Massachusetts found that 68% of all bedbug infestations require three or more treatments, 26% require two treatments, and 6% require just one. Another concern with pesticide use is the development of resistance to the pesticides used in the treatment of bed bugs. The Integrated Pest Management Association found that by 1956, DDT resistance was so widespread that the control method had to be changed to Malathion. Results from current research conducted by the University of Kentucky show that bed bug resistance to insecticidal products that have pyrethroids as an active ingredient has become significant. The excessive use of pesticide solutions may result in the bed bug developing greater resistance to current methodologies. Oftentimes this leads to overcompensating by increasing amounts of chemicals. This can be a dangerous practice. Bed Bugs & Beyond is a simpler control methodology which alters a bed bug’s natural environment, making it lethal to the bedbug. Pesticides can also pose a threat to the environment. DDT was an effective chemical in significantly treating bed bug occurrences in the United States before it was banned in 1972 because of the reproductive effects to birds from chronic exposure to DDT. Bird exposure to this insecticide mainly occurs through the consumption of aquatic and/or terrestrial species that have been exposed to DDT (WHO 1989). Like other chemicals, DDT was able to work its way through the ecosystem and cause adverse health and reproductive effects to many animals in the food chain.
